title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the relationship between deer population and biodiversity in forest A, such as any of the following:

· In Forest A, the density of the deer population is high, and the biodiversity is low.

· In Forest A, as density of the deer population increases, biodiversity decreases.

· There is an inverse relationship between deer population density and plant biodiversity.

title: Part C

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence to agree or disagree with the hikers’ request that the city take action by trapping and relocating possums away from Forest C to reduce the tick population, such as any of the following:

· The hikers’ request that relocating the possum would decrease the tick population should be disagreed with because possums feed on ticks.

· The hiker’s request should be disagreed with because possum eat ticks, so relocating the possums would increase, not decrease the tick population

· The hiker’s request should be disagreed with because possums are highly effective at removing young ticks, killing many of the ticks when they are young, so possums should remain in the forest to help prevent the tick population from increasing.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one variable that was not mentioned in the description that could affect the results of the investigation and does not explain how that variable could affect the results, such as any of the following:

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the steps that likely led to the formation of soil in the study area, such as any of the following:

· Wind and precipitation weather rock, lichens and mosses grow on the surface of rocks and slowly breakdown the rock, forming soil.

· The retreating glaciers left behind bare bedrock. Organisms from nearby habitats begin to build soil by breaking down exposed bedrock/wind brings in soil materials to the area.

· Primary succession occurs when pioneer species such as lichen, move into the unoccupied habitat and alter the conditions from bare bedrock to more fertile soil.

The response describes the steps that likely led to the formation of soil in the study area, such as one of the following:

· Wind and precipitation weather rock, lichens and mosses grow on the surface of rocks and slowly breakdown the rock, forming soil.

· The retreating glaciers left behind bare bedrock. Organisms from nearby habitats begin to build soil by breaking down exposed bedrock/wind brings in soil materials to the area.

· Primary succession occurs when pioneer species such as lichen, move into the unoccupied habitat and alter the conditions from bare bedrock to more fertile soil.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe an anthropogenic occurrence that could result in soil formation from similar initial conditions to those described in part (i), such as any of the following:

· An abandoned parking lot is similar to the bare bedrock left behind by glaciers since there is no soil or vegetation.

· A nuclear explosion is similar to bare bedrock left behind by glaciers because there would be no soil and no surviving plants/animals.

· Mountain top removal is similar to bare bedrock left behind by glaciers because there would be no soil and no surviving plants/animals.
